questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-4, B-3, C-5, D-2

 

Correct matching is.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Subcostal vessels and nerve run along the inferior border of the 12th rib. They are not directly associated with any of the specific diaphragmatic openings but are related to the area just below the ribcage They pass behind the lateral arcuate ligament.
  2. The sympathetic trunk runs vertically along the vertebral column. It is located posteriorly in the abdomen and is not directly associated with the diaphragmatic openings but lies behind the medial arcuate ligament.
  3. Superior epigastric vessels are continuations of the internal thoracic (mammary) artery and vein. They travel through the space of Larrey, which is a gap between the sternal and costal attachments of the diaphragm on either side.
  4. The thoracic duct is the main lymphatic duct of the body. It ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm at the level of T12.
  5. The phrenic nerve provides the main motor supply to the diaphragm. The right phrenic nerve enters the thoracic cavity and passes through the caval opening (IVC opening) in the diaphragm at the level of T8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minor openings in Diaphragm:

 

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 180

choices.text: 28 – 32 weeks
32 – 34 weeks
24 – 30 weeks
24 – 28 weeks

questions.text: Extremely preterm is defined as preterm birth at:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. 24-28 weeks.

Educational Obective: 

Preterm is defined as period of gestation between 24w – 36w (+6d)

  • Extremely preterm is 24 – 28w
  • Very preterm is 28 – 32 w
  • Moderate preterm is 32 – 34 w
  • Late preterm is 34w – 36w (+6d)

 

 

Ref: Page no: 804, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 24 – 28 weeks
26 – 30 weeks
28 -32 weeks
32 – 34 weeks

questions.text: Very preterm is defined as preterm birth at:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 28- 32weeks

Educational Obective: 

Preterm is defined as period of gestation between 24w – 36w (+6d)

  • Extremely preterm is 24 – 28w
  • Very preterm is 28 – 32 w
  • Moderate preterm is 32 – 34 w
  • Late preterm is 34w – 36w (+6d)

 

 

Ref: Page no: 804, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: All are immediate complications of a preterm neonate except.
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Hyperglycemia

Let's Discuss all the Options

  • Option A: Hyperbilirubinemia: Hyoerbilirubinemia and neonatal jaundice is more common in preterm neonates
  • Option B: Hyperglycemia: In preterm neonates, hypoglycemia is more common as the liver is not mature 
  • Option C:  Intra ventricular hemorrhage: Intra ventricular hemorrhage is more common in preterm neonates
  • Option D: Necrotizing Enterocolitis: Necrotizing Enterocolitis is more common i preterm neonates

 

Educational Obective: 

Complications of a preterm neonate

Ref: Page no: 805, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Transvaginal scan at 12 weeks
Trans abdominal scan at 12 weeks
Transvaginal scan at 16 weeks
Transabdominal scan at 16 weeks

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1L0 presents to the OPD at 8 weeks. She has a history of a previous preterm delivery at 32 weeks. A cervical length measurement is advised. Which of these statements regarding cervical length measurement is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Transvaginal scan at 16 week  

Let's Discuss all the Options: 

  • Option A: Transvaginal scan at 12 weeks: Although the cervical length can be measured during the Level 1 scan (11-14 weeks), a better predictor is a short cervix (< 2.5 cm) between 16-24 weeks
  • Option B: Transabdominal scan at 12 weeks: A transvaginal scan is preferred for cervical length measurement
  • Option C: Transvaginal scan at 16 weeks is correct as an ultrasound measurement done between 16-24 weeks is a predictor of preterm labor. A cervical length < 2.5 cm (between 16-24 weeks) is a predictor for preterm labor
  • Option D: Transabdominal scan at 16 weeks: Although 16 weeks is a good time to check the cervical length on ultraosund, it is better visualized and measured by a trans vaginal scan. 

Educational Objective:

  • Cervical length measurement is a predictor of preterm birth. 
  • Cervical length is measured by a Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) at 16 – 24 weeks
  • Cervical length < 25 mm is a predictor for preterm birth

 

Ref: Page no: 815, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Routine antenatal care
Follow up ultrasound at 32 weeks
Start Progesterone
McDonald’s cervical cerclage

questions.text: A 26-year-old primi presents at 18 weeks for a routine antenatal checkup. She has no complaints.  The measurement shown in the image below was taken and was 2.2 cm. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Start progesterone.

  •  The image seen is that of a cervical length on ultrasound 
  • Cervical length measurement is  done as a routine screening in the mid trimester (!6 - 24 weeks)
  • An incidentally diagnosed short cervix in the absence of a prior preterm birth/ mid trimester loss is not an indication for cerclage.
  • Vaginal progesterone should be started in this patient serial ultrasound measurements of cervical length (2-3 weekly)
  • Only if there is both a short cervix and 1 or more prior preterm births/ mid trimester abortions, is cervical cerclage done to prevent preterm labor. 

Let's Discuss the Other Options

  • Option A: Routine antenatal care: IF the cervical length is < 2.5 cm between 16-24 weeks, it is a predictor for preterm birth. The patient should be informed of the risk and increased moniotring done. Vaginal progesterones should be started with serial measurements of cervical length every 2-3 weeks.
  • Option B: Follow up ultrasound at 32 weeks: Follow up scans for measurement of cervical langth should be done every 2- weeks
  • Option D: McDonald cervical cerclage: cerclage should be considered if there is a prior preterm birth/ mid trimester loss with a short cervix (<2.5 cm between 16-24 weeks)

Educational Objective:

  • Cervical length measurement is  done as a routine screening in the mid trimester (!6 - 24 weeks)
  • An incidentally diagnosed short cervix in the absence of a prior preterm birth/ mid trimester loss is not an indication for cerclage.
  • Vaginal progesterone should be started in this patient serial ultrasound measurements of cervical length (2-3 weekly)
  • Only if there is both a short cervix and 1 or more prior preterm births/ mid trimester abortions, is cervical cerclage done to prevent preterm labor. 

Ref: Page no: 815, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: All are biochemical markers of preterm delivery found in cervico-vaginal secretions except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Beta hCG

 

  • Levels of Beta hCG do not predict preterm labor

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Predictors of preterm labor:

 

  1. USG measurement of cervical length < 25 mm at 16 â€“ 24 weeks
  2. Biochemical markers in the cervico-vaginal secretions:
    • Fetal fibronectin
    • Insulin like growth factor binding protein
    • Placental alpha macroglobulin

 

Ref: Page no: 814, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Abruptio placentae
Preterm labor

questions.text: A 24 y G2P1 presents to the labor room at 32 weeks with complaints of abdominal pain and backache. Her BP is 120/80 mmHg. The uterus is 32 weeks size and there is occasional hardening at the fundus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Preterm labor

The most likely diagnosis is preterm labor based on symptoms and signs i.e 32 weeks gestation with abdominal pain, backache and hardening of the uterus.

Other Options

  • Option A: Abruption is unlikely as there is no bleeding. The uterus corresponds to the POG and there is no tenderness. However to diagnose preterm labor, cervical dilatation and effacement should also be present
  • Option B: There is no h/o urinary symptoms mentioned and this rule out UTI
  • Option D: There is no h/o vaginal leaking given and this rules our Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes

Educational Objective: 

  • Preterm labor is defined (by WHO) as the onset of regular uterine contractions (before 37 weeks) i.e. at least 4 contractions in 20 minutes assocuated with cervical dilatation of > 1 cm or effacement > 80%

 

Ref: Page no: 814, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 29 y G2 presents at 33 weeks in preterm labor. Which of the following tocolytics is contra-indicated?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Indomethacin

  • Indomethacin is c/I beyond 32 weeks in view of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

Educational Objective:

Tocolytics used in Preterm Labor

 

Ref: Page no: 826, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: The antibiotic of choice in PPROM is:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Erythromycin

In PPROM there is an increased risk of chorioamnionitis, neonatal sepsis and puerperal sepsis.

  • To prevent these, prophylactic antibiotics are started in women who present with PPROM 
  • The antibiotic of choice in PPROM is erythromycin (RCOG guidleines)

Educational Objective:

The following are the recommendations for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with PPROM

 

Ref: Page no: 822, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Fetal distress

questions.text: A 30-year G2P1L1 presents at 31 weeks to the labor room with c/o leaking and mild abdominal pain. All the below are absolute contra-indications to tocolysis except?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. oligohydramnios

Oligohydrmanios is NOT a c/i to tocolysis

Absolute contra-indications to tocolysis include the following:

  1.  
  • Active labor
  • Fetal distress
  • Fetal death
  • Eclampsia
  • Anomalies not compatible to life
  • Abruptio placentae
  • Pregnancy > 34 weeks
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Antepartum hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

Absolute contra-indications to tocolysis include the following:

  1.  
  • Active labor
  • Fetal distress
  • Fetal death
  • Eclampsia
  • Anomalies not compatible to life
  • Abruptio placentae
  • Pregnancy > 34 weeks
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Antepartum hemorrhage

(Ref: Page no: 821, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition)

choices.text: Threatened abortion in the 1st trimester
Progesterone intake
Vitamin C deficiency
Periodontal infection

questions.text: All are risk factors for preterm labor except:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Progesterone intake       

  • Progesterone causes uterine relaxation and is used in the treatment of preterm labor 
  • Causes and Risk factors for preterm labor are:

Other Options:

  • Option A: Threatened abortion in the 1st trimester: This is a risk factor for preterm labor. It is also a risk factor for abruption, fetal growth restriciton and intra uterine fetal demise
  • Option C: Vitamin C deficiency: Nutritional deficiencies including vitamin C deficiency have been implicated in preterm labor
  • Option D: Periodontal infection: This has also been implicated in preterm labor. 

Educational Objective: 

Causes of Preterm Labor

Direct causes 

  1. Spontaneous preterm labor
    1. Overdistended uterus (polyhydramnios, multiple pregnancy)
    2. Maternal – Fetal Stress (nutrition, diabetes, psychological etc.)
    3. Cervical dysfunction (congenital/ acquired following conization/ amputation/ cervical trauma
    4. Intrauterine Infection
    5. Placental Abruption
    6. Mullerian Anomalies
  2. Preterm Prelabor Rupture of Membranes (PPROM)
  3. Medically indicated or iatrogenic
    • Maternal: Pre-eclampsia, Eclampsia, APH, GDM
    • Fetal: IUGR, oligohydramnios, Rh isoimmunization
  4. Due to multiple pregnancy

Contributory Factors

  • h/o Threatened abortion 
  • h/o Previous preterm birth
  • Congenital Mullerian anomalies
  • Lifestyle factors (smoking)
  • Extremes of age
  • Poverty, malnutrition, Vitamin C deficiency
  • Interval between pregnancies (both reduced and increased)
  • Bacterial vaginosis (spontaneous abortion, PPROM, chorioamnionitis and Preterm labor)
  • Periodontal disease (chronic anaerobic inflammation of the gums)
  • Depression, anxiety
  • Hard labor/ severe physical exertion

 

 

Ref: Page no: 809, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Functional deficiency of which hormone causes preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Progesterone

  • Progesterone is the main hormone supporting pregnancy
  • A functional deficiency leads to the onset of labor

Educational Objective:

 

  • Progesterone is the main hormone supporting pregnancy
  • A functional deficiency leads to the onset of labor

Ref: Page no: 810, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Which of the following alphabet signs is the first to be seen on ultrasound in preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Y

n the progress of cervical changes in preterm labor, On TVS, the following can be seen:

  • T-normal cervix
  • Y-dilatation of the internal os
  • V-funneling of the cervical canal
  • U-dilatation of both internal and external os

 

 

Educational Objective: 

In the progress of cervical changes in preterm labor, on TVS, the following can be seen:

  • T-normal cervix
  • Y-dilatation of the internal os
  • V-funneling of the cervical canal
  • U-dilatation of both internal and external os

 

(Ref: Page no: 815, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition)

choices.text: Foul smelling discharge

questions.text: All are signs of chorioamnionitis except:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Fetal bradycardia

Fetal tachycardia is a sign of chorioamnionitis (not bradycardia)

Educational Objective: 

Chorioamnionitis:

    • Chorioamnionitis is intra-amniotic infection and inflammation
    • Maternal temp > 390C – ESSENTIAL (only definitive sign of chorioamnionitis)
    • Other features:
      • Maternal tachycardia
      • Fetal tachycardia
      • Maternal leukocytosis
      • Uterine tenderness
      • Foul smelling discharge
      • Raised TLC
      • Raised CRP
      • HVS culture positive

 

Ref: Page no: 821, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 24 yr primi presents at 33 weeks with abdominal pain. One examination the os is 2 cm dilated and early effaced. She has no additional risk factor, and her BP is 110/ 70 mmHg. Tocolytics and corticosteroids are administered. The drug of choice for tocolysis in preterm labor is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nifedipine

 

The first line for tocolysis is CCBs and the most commonly used tocolytic is nifedipine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ritodrine: This is a beta 2 agonist and is is not a preferred tocolytic due to its high side effect profile which includes hypotension, tachycardia, pulmonary edema and hyperglycemia

 

Option C. Indomethacin: This is also not preferred especially if > 32 weeks as it can lead to premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

 

Option D. Atosiban: Although this drug has an excellent side effect profile, it is not usually used as a 1st line drug due to its cost. It acts as an oxytocin receptor antagonist

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium channel blockers are the tocolytci agent of choice if no contra-indication

 

Ref: Page no 824, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 40-year woman, known for mitral stenosis, presents at 30 weeks in preterm labor. Which of the following tocolytics is safe?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Atosiban

  • Atosiban is an oxytocin receptor antagonist.
  • It has fewer side effects and is safe in medical complications like DM, heart disease
  • Drawback: It is expensive

Other Options:

  • Calcium Channel Blockers (Nifedepine) and Beta2 agonists (isoxuprine and ternbutaline) are contra-indicated in heart disease in pregnancy

Educational Objective:

  • Atosiban is an oxytocin receptor antagonist.
  • It has fewer side effects and is safe in medical complications like DM, heart disease
  • Drawback: It is expensive

 

Ref: Page no: 826, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: As an antihypertensive
As a neuroprotective agent in preterm labor
In Severe preeclampsia
Tocolysis in preterm labor

questions.text: In obstetrics, MgSO4 is used as all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. As an antihypertensive

MgSO4 can be used in all the options mentioned EXCEPT as an anti-hypertensive

Educational Objective:

 

MgSO4 is not given to treat hypertension.

Magnesium ions exert a specific anticonvulsant action on the cerebral cortex.

choices.text: Alpha methyldopa

questions.text: All the following drugs are uterine relaxants except:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Alpha methyldopa

  • Alpha methyl dopa is antihypertensive
  • All the others are uterine relaxants

Educational Objective: 

Summary of Tocolytics

 

 

(Ref: Page no: 826, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition)

questions.text: A 21 y G2P1 with a history of a prior preterm delivery presents at 32 weeks with abdominal pain. How will you confirm she is in preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vaginal examination for cervical dilatation

 

  • Preterm labor is defined as onset of labor prior to 37 weeks of gestation

 

Preterm labor is defined as regular uterine contractions (â‰¥4 in 20 min or â‰¥8 in 60 min) plus one of the following:

 

  • Cervical dilation â‰¥3 cm
  • Cervical length â‰¤20 mm on transvaginal ultrasound
  • Cervical length 20â€“30 mm with positive fetal fibronectin

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Cervical length on ultrasound: This is a predictor of preterm labor and does not define preterm labor

 

Option B: Fetal fibronectin: This is a biochemical predictor of preterm labor

 

Option C: Tocography: This means measurement of uterine pressure and can be done by ambulatory home tocography and is also a predictor of preterm labor

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Preterm labor is defined as onset of labor prior to 37 weeks of gestation
  • The diagnosis is based on
  • Cervical dilation â‰¥3 cm OR cervical length â‰¤20 mm OR cervical length 20â€“30 mm with positive fetal fibronectin, with regular contraction

 

Ref: ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 234 (2021); Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Chapter 42

choices.text: Previous history of neonate with GBS disease
GBS bacteriuria in present pregnancy
Rupture of membranes > 18 h
Intrapartum temperature > 990F

questions.text: Intrapartum prophylaxis for Group B streptococcal prophylaxis is indicated in all the following situations except?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Intrapartum temperature > 990F

Intrapartum prophylaxis for gp B streptococcal infection is if there is intrapartum fever > 100.4 F

Educational Objective:

Group B Streptococcus Infection & Prophylaxis

    • Streptococcus agalactiae: Group B organism that colonizes GIT & GUT in 10 – 25% of pregnant women
    • Leading infectious cause of mortality and morbidity in infants in the USA
    • As per ACOG: Universal rectovaginal screening for GBS at 35 – 37 weeks
    • Intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis for carriers or for those with GBS bacteriuria or h/o previous infant with GBS disease
    • Intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis also for:
      • Delivery < 37 weeks
      • Amniotic membrane rupture > 18h
      • Intrapartum temp > 100.4
      • Intrapartum NAAT positive for GBS
    • Recommended antibiotic:
      • Penicillin G 5 million units IV initial then 2.5 million units 4 hourly till delivery
      • Alternate: Ampicillin
      • If penicillin allergy: Cefazolin or Clindamycin or Vancomycin

 

Ref: Page no 1220, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 6 mg 2 doses 24th hourly IM
6 mg 4 doses 12th hourly IM
12 mg 2 doses 12th hourly IM
12 mg 2 doses 24th hourly IM

questions.text: The dose of betamethasone for fetal lung maturity is:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. 12 mg 2 doses 24th hourly IM

  • Corticosteroids (Dexamthasone or betamethasone) can be given for ataining fetal lung maturity if a preterm delivery before 34 weeks is anticipated 
  • Dexamethasone is given as 6mg IM 4 doses 12th hourly
  • Betamethasone is given as 12mg IM 2 doses 24 hours apart

Educational Objective:

Role of corticosteroids in fetal lung maturity:

  • Accelerate fetal lung maturity (Increases surfactant production)
  • 24 – 34 weeks; anticipated to deliver within 7 days
  • Some role in late preterm also; can be considered in up to 366/7
  • Lower rates of
    • Perinatal death
    • Neonatal death
    • RDS
    • Intraventricular hemorrhage
    • Necrotizing enterocolitis
    • Need for mechanical ventilation
  • Two 12-mg doses of betamethasone given intramuscularly 24 hours apart OR
  • Four 6-mg doses of dexamethasone administered intramuscularly every 12 hours
  • Both reduce RDS equally
  • There is an additional benefit of betamethasone in reducing the incidence of IVH and NEC
  • No benefit of repeated doses
  • Rescue dose may be considered in < 34 weeks and anticipated delivery within 7 days with last received dose > 14 days ago (ACOG)

 

Ref: page no 825, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Fetal growth restriction
Respiratory Distress Syndrome

questions.text: Corticosteroids given before 34 weeks, are known to reduce the incidence of all the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Fetal growth restriction

Corticosteroids reduce the rates of: 

 

  • Perinatal death
  • Neonatal death
  • RDS
  • Intraventricular hemorrhage
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • Need for mechanical ventilation

Educational Objective: 

Role of corticosteroids in fetal lung maturity:

  • Accelerate fetal lung maturity (Increases surfactant production)
  • 24 – 34 weeks; anticipated to deliver within 7 days
  • Some role in late preterm also; can be considered in up to 366/7
  • Lower rates of
    • Perinatal death
    • Neonatal death
    • RDS
    • Intraventricular hemorrhage
    • Necrotizing enterocolitis
    • Need for mechanical ventilation

Ref: Page no 825, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is an oxytocin receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Atosiban

  • Atosiban is an oxytocin receptor antagonist and used as tocolytic
  • It is safely given in women having heart disease/ DM and HTN

Other Options:

  • Option B: Isoxsuprine: This is a tocolytic and is a beta agonist. It causes smooth muscle relaxation
  • Option C: Misoprostol: This is PGE1 and is a uterotonic, i.e. it causes uterine contractions
  • Option D: Progesterone: This is a hormone that supports pregnancy by causing uterine quiesence

Educational Objective: 

  • Atosiban is an oxytocin receptor antagonist and used as tocolytic
  • It is safely given in women having heart disease/ DM and HTN

Ref: Page no 824, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Start nifedipine and give corticosteroids
Check L/S ratio for fetal lung maturity before giving corticosteroids
Start indomethacin and give corticosteroids
Do an ultrasound and if EFW is > 2 kg, plan delivery

questions.text: A 24 yr. G2 presents at 33 weeks with intermittent abdominal pain. On vaginal examination, the cervix is 2 cm dilated and 50% effaced. What is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Start nifedipine and give corticosteroids

  • This is a patient with preterm labor (POG is 33 weeks in labor)
  • The management should include corticosteroids and tocolysis
  • Tocolytic of choice is nifedipine.
  • Tocolytics are given before 34 weeks and buys time to give corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity.

Other Options:

  • Option B: Check L/S ratio for fetal lung maturity before giving corticosteroids: There is no role of checking the L/S ratio unless the Period of gestation was in doubt
  • Option C: Start indomethacin and give corticosteroids: Indomethacin should not be given afger 32 weeks as it can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
  • Option D: Do an ultrasound and if EFW is > 2 kg, plan delivery: There is no role of Ultrasound in this patient as preterm labor is a clinical diagnosis.

Educational Objective:

  • In established preterm labor < 34 weeks, the management should be 
    • Tocolysis
    • In-utero transfer to a tertiary care neonatal unit
    • Corticosteroids

Ref: Page no 825, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding tocolysis are correct?

 

  1. Atosiban is an oxytocin receptor antagonist 
  2. Indomethacin causes oligohydramnios which is irreversible and persists even with discontinuation of therapy
  3. B Adrenergic receptor agonists can cause serious maternal morbidity including pulmonary edema, cardiac arrhythmias and myocardial ischemia
  4. Prolonged use of MgSO4 given to arrest preterm labor can cause bone thinning and fractures in fetuses exposed for more than 5-7 days.
questions.solution:
Ans: D. 1,3,4

  • Indomethacin causes oligohydramnios which is reversible with drug discontinuation
  • Indomethacin also causes Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus if given > 32 weeks
  • Atosiban is an oxytocin receptor antagonist
  • Beta adrenergic receptor agonists like ritodrine and Isoxsuprine are known to cause tachycardia, hypotension, pulmonary edema, myocardial ischemia and cardiac arrhythmias
  • Prolonged use of MgSO4 given to arrest preterm labor can cause bone thinning and fractures in fetuses exposed for more than 5-7 days due to low calcium levels in the fetus

 

Ref: Page no 806, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition
